ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Good foundation in basic calculus, feel confident in continuing to more advanced courses
I developed my understanding of calculus and strengthened my logical reasoning skills.
By taking this course, I felt I was able to dive deeper into calculus and learn more about its applications in real world life settings.
Basic calculus
Calculus 112.
I learned about limits, differentiation, integrals, and differential equations.
Differentiation and integration, applications of both.
I learned a deeper understanding of calculus, particularly its applications to life.
To use resources, to read the textbook
Learned the start of calculus. Worked mostly with derivatives, integrals and different theorems.
I gained skills and knowledge in calculus one. Limits, derivatives, some integrals and application of these concepts.
Learned the basic principles of calculus I

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I found this course to be hard to follow at times and found that lectures did not really help me. However, the peer tutors were extremely helpful.
I didn't learn anything in lecture, only through online homework and psets. The strengths of the course were the peer tutors, without whom I wouldn't have passed.
n/a

Strengths: the material on the exams was consistent so if you knew the material you wouldn't get blindsided
Weaknesses: Differences in what different sections learned based on the instructor.
Improvement suggestion: Make sure the sections are pretty standardized at least in terms of the methods used to solve things and the material covered.
Strengths are in the assigned homework that included videos explaining each concept. Weakness is the broad variation in teaching across sections.
I think the curriculum could have been more standardized because there were some different topics being taught between different sections.
A better understanding of what type of questions will be on the exams and understanding the necessity for past knowledge
The course outline is very clear and the teaching method is great. They give many studying resources too. Not many weaknesses.
I liked the smaller class for instruction. I liked the ximera site to reinforce the concept. Sometimes, my professor would get sidetracked but other than that it was a good course.
The classes covered topics in a manner that were much easier than the tests and the PSETS.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes; good way to complete a QR requirement and get the basic knowledge of math you need to know to proceed in college.
Yes. I think Professor Geiger made calculus accessible and provided us with the necessary preparation to succeed in the course.
If they want to gain a basic understanding of calculus then yes I would recommend it.
I wouldn't recommend this class unless you need it as a prerequisite
Yes. It's a foundational math class.
Yes, the concepts are explained well and my professor and TAs were always helpful.
Yes, only if the student genuinely enjoys calculus. I do not like math, but the class was not terrible.
Yes but I would look into different teachers and select a section based on that because the strength of different teachers varies greatly in this course.
If they enjoy calculus yes but if its just to get a QR credit no because its very challenging and not enjoyable
I would recommend to people who are starting calculus.
I would. It was a good introduction calculus course and will set me up well for future math and engineering classes.
If needed as a requirement. Make sure to reach out to peer tutors early on and not procrastinate because the topics will quickly add up.
